document.docTitle: Impairment of botrydial production in Botrytis cinerea allows the isolation of undescribed polyketides and reveals new insights into the botcinins biosynthetic pathway

paragraph.docTitle:
Impairment of botrydial production in
Botrytis cinerea
allows the isolation of undescribed polyketides and reveals new insights into the botcinins biosynthetic pathway

subSection.paragraph:
Rosario Hern´andez-Gal´an a , Muriel Viaud b , Isidro G. Collado
a, *

paragraph.docAuthorAffiliation: Departamento de Química Org´anica , Facultad de Ciencias, Campus Universitario Río San Pedro s/n, Torre sur, 4a planta, Universidad de C´adiz, 11510, Puerto Real,

subSection.paragraph: b Universite´Paris-Saclay, INRAE, AgroParisTech, UMR BIOGER, Avenue Lucien Br´etigni`eres , 78850, Thiverval-Grignon, France
A R T I C L E I N F O
Genome
Polyketides
Botcinins
Botrylactones
Cinbotolides
A B S T R A C T

Botrytis cinerea
is a necrotrophic fungal pathogen that affects a total of 586 genera representing approximately 1400 plant species. This pathogen produces two families of phytotoxins involved in its infection process i.e. botrydial and its relatives, and botcinic and botcineric acids and their relatives, botcinins. The botrydial biosynthetic cluster consists of seven genes, where the gene BcBOT4 encodes a cytochrome P450 monooxygenase that was shown to catalyse regio- and stereospecific hydroxylation at position C-4 of the presilphiperfolan-8-β- ol skeleton. The null mutant
bcbot4 Δ
halted the production of botrydial and its derivatives, and instead accumulated tricyclic presilphiperfolane alcohol and overproduced a significant number of polyketides. A detailed study of the
bcbot4 Δ
mutant led us to the isolation and characterization of five undescribed polyketides, three derived from botcinic and botcineric acids (botcinins H, I, J), one derived from the initial pentaketide (botcinin K), and one cinbotolide derivative (cinbotolide D). Botcinins are tetra-methylated tetraketides biosynthesized by the sequential assembly of a pentaketide (C10) based on an acetate primer unit which is lost through a retro-Claisen type C–C bond cleavage. The structural characterization of botcinin K showed a basic chemical structure corresponding to a botcinin (C14) derivative obtained directly from the original per-methylated pentaketide leading to the biosynthesis of botrylactone and other botcinins, confirming the previously proposed biosynthetic route.
E-mail address: isidro.gonzalez@uca.es (I.G. Collado).
1 These authors contributed equally to this work.

Additionally, a family of sporogenic eremophilenols potentially used by
B. cinerea
as effectors to circumvent plant chemical defenses, has recently been reported 9–20 ( Pinedo et al., 2016 ; Suarez´et al., 2018).

Moreover, the botrydial biosynthetic cluster consists of seven genes codifying for one sesquiterpene cyclase BcBOT2, three P450 monooxygenases, BcBOT1, BcBOT3 and BcBOT4, one acetyl transferase BcBOT5, one dehydrogenases BcBOT7, and the putative Zn(II) 2 Cys 6 transcription factor BcBOT6 ( Pinedo et al., 2008 ; Moraga et al., 2016 ). The gene BcBOT4 encodes a cytochrome P450 monooxygenase that was shown to catalyse regio- and stereospecific hydroxylation at position C-4 of the presilphiperfolan-8-β- ol skeleton ( Moraga et al., 2016 ). The null mutant
bcbot4 Δ
abolished the production of botrydial and its derivatives, and instead accumulated the tricyclic presilphiperfolane alcohol and overproduced a significant number of polyketides ( Moraga et al., 2016 ; Porquier et al., 2016 ).

A detailed study of the null mutant in the BcBOT 4 gene led us to characterize four undescribed botcinin derivatives and one cinbotolide, cinbotolide D. This paper addresses the structural characterization of the unreported polyketides and confirms the biosynthetic route to botrylactones and botcinins.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Some metabolites isolated from B. cinerea .

subSection.paragraph:
A KO DNA cassette containing a nourseothricin resistance gene replacing the BcBOT4 gene, was constructed by PCR fusion and employed to transform protoplasts of the BO5.10 wild-type strains ( Moraga et al., 2016 ). The transformation resulted in two independent
bcbot4 Δ
mutants and the integration of the replacement fragment at the targeted loci the genome was verified by PCR analysis.

The null
bcbot4 Δ
mutants, derived from the B05.10 strain, were grown on a solid malt agar medium as described in the experimental section. Broths were extracted with ethyl acetate (EtOAc) and the extracts separated by column chromatography using hexane:EtOAc mixtures of increasing polarity until reaching 100% of EtOAc. Both independent mutants displayed similar chemical patterns. 1 H-NMR spectra of medium polarity fractions showed the presence of different mixtures of botcinins which were subjected to HPLC chromatography to obtain pure compounds which were then characterized by extensive NMR experiments.

As expected, the null mutant accumulated the tricyclic presilphiperfolane-8β- ol, the key intermediate in botrydial biosynthesis ( Pinedo et al., 2008 ; Moraga et al., 2016 ; Porquier et al., 2016 ). In addition to known polyketides previously reported, ( Tani et al., 2005 , 2006 ; Moraga et al., 2016 ), compounds 21–25 , Fig. 2 , were obtained and their structures were characterized by extensive mono- and bidimensional NMR experiments.

The 1 H-NMR spectrum of compound 21 showed characteristic signals of the basic bicyclic skeleton of botcinin and signals corresponding to the side chain at C-7 were clearly missing. Thus, three signal doublets at δ 1.10, 1.20, 1.22, and one singlet (δ 1.22), integrating three protons each, were assigned to the four methyl groups on carbons C-2, C-6, C-8 and C-4, respectively. Two signals, one at δ 3.1 (dq, J = 10, 7.0 Hz) and another at δ 2.0 (m), were assigned to protons H-2, and H-6 respectively. Also, four signals characteristic of protons germinal to oxygenated function at δ 3.50 (dq, J = 9.7, 6.4 Hz), 3.7 (d, J = 11 Hz), 2.9 (t, J = 10 Hz), 5.4 (d, J = 9.7 Hz), were assigned to protons H-8, H-5, H-7 and H-3. Lastly, a singlet at δ 2.1 corresponded to the methyl of the acetate group on carbon C-3. Spectroscopic constants were consistent with structure 21 ( Fig. 2 ), corresponding to the compound obtained from hydrogenation of the double bond in the side chain of botcinin A ( 4 ), and subsequent acid hydrolysis (HCl, 12 M) to remove the acyl portion ( Tani et al., 2005 ). The absolute configuration of 21 has been reported ( Tani et al., 2005 ). This is the first time that this compound has been isolated and we have named it botcinin H.

Compounds 22–24 displayed a pattern of NMR signals characteristic of botcinins ( Tani et al., 2005 , 2006 ). The 13 C-NMR for compound 22 contained 20 signals which, considered jointly with the HRMS, were consistent with the molecular formula C 20 H 30 O 7 . These data, and the absence of NMR spectra signals corresponding to the acetyl group at C-3, indicated a side chain containing eight carbon atoms.

The most significant differences were observed in the signals of the characteristic side chain. The multiplicity of vinylic signals at carbons C-2 ′ and C-3 ′ changed from two double doublets to two doublets. On the other hand, the absence of the signal in the 1 H-NMR spectrum of the geminal proton to a hydroxyl group at C-4 ′ and instead the presence, in the 13 C-NMR spectrum, of a carbonyl group, were observed. Thus the vinilic protons (H-2 ′ and H-3 ′ ) signals appeared as two doublets at δ 6.7 and 7.11, J = 16.0 Hz, indicating an E geometry of the double bond, which along with the carbonyl signal to 199.5 ppm indicated that the compound 22 possessed an octenoyl side chain with a carbonyl group at C-4 ′ . This proposed structure 22 was confirmed by HMBC (supplementary Table S1) experiments showing correlations of H-2 ′ and H-3 ′ with C-1 ′ and with the carbonyl C-4 ′ , respectively; and of H-5 ′ with carbons C-4 ′ , C-6 ′ and C-7 ′ . The rest of the signals found in the NMR spectra and all the correlations in the HMBC and HSQC experiments were consistent with the basic structure 3- O -deacetyl botcinin A ( Tani et al., 2006 ), with a chain of ( E )-4 ′ -oxooct-2 ′ -enoyloxy attached to the pyrane ring at C-7. This new chemical structure of botcinin was named botcinin I.

The 1 H-NMR signal pattern of compound 23 resembled that of compound 22 , the most notable differences being the presence of an acetyl group situated at C-3 and the coupling constants of the two doublet signals corresponding to the vinylic group at C-2 ′ -C-3 ′ , ( J = 12.1 Hz), indicating a Z geometry for the double bond.

The HRMS supported by the 13 C NMR spectrum showed that compound 23 possessed a molecular formula of C 24 H 36 O 8 indicating that, in addition to an acetyl group, compound 23 had a side chain of ten carbon atoms. COSY, HSQC and HMBC spectra (supplementary Table S2) were consistent with a basic structure of botcinin A with a ( Z )-4 ′ -oxodec-2 ′ - enoyloxy chain at the C-7 carbon which was named botcinin J.

The HRMS and 13 C-NMR of compound 24 indicated a formula of C 22 H 34 O 7 . The NMR spectra of this compound displayed a pattern of signals characteristic of a basic botcinin skeleton with a side chain of eight carbon atoms attached at C-7. The main differences observed in its 1 H-NMR were the multiplicity of the signals corresponding to the double bond at C-2 ′ - C-3 ′ , the absence of the signal of a geminal proton to a hydroxyl group in the side chain, and the signals multiplicity of methyl groups which appeared as two doublets and two singlets instead of three doublets and one singlet.

The multiplicity of vinylic signals at carbons C-2 ′ and C-3 ′ appeared as two double triplets at δ 5.8 (dt, J = 15.6, 1.7 Hz) and 7.0 (dt, J = 15.6, 7 Hz), indicating the absence of the characteristic hydroxyl group at C-4 ′ and, based on the coupling constant, an E geometry for the double bond. Particularly interesting was the change observed in the multiplicity of one methyl group which changed to singlet, indicating the presence of a new organic function in the structure. The study of signals in the 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectra, along with HSQC and HMBC experiments, allowed us to assign protons H-3, H-5, H-6 and H-7, the methyl groups at C-2, C-4 and C-6, and all signals corresponding to side chain protons and carbons.

The main differences were at carbon C-8 where the correlations observed in the HMBC of H-14 with C-7, C-8, C-9, and H-7α with C-1 ′ , C-9, C-13 and C-14, indicated the presence of a geminal acetyl group to the methyl at C-8. Examination of the HSQC, HMBC and COSY spectra enabled all the carbon and their associated 1 H NMR signals to be assigned (Table S3).

The stereochemistry of compound 24 was deduced based on the absolute stereochemistry assigned to the basic skeleton of botcinin A ( Tani et al., 2005 ), while the stereochemistry in the environment surrounding carbon C-8 was based on the interactions observed in the nOe experiments (Table S3). Thus, the β disposition for the methyl group at C-8 was deduced from the interactions of proton H-14 with H-6 and H-12; and those observed between H-11 and H-2, H-6 and H-14. The α stereochemistry assigned to the acetyl group was confirmed by interactions of H-7α with H-10, H-13 and H-5, and the nOe observed between H-3α and protons H-2, H-5, H-10. These nOe interactions allowed us to propose structure 24 for this botcinin derivative which was named botcinin K.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2. Botcinins and cinbotolide isolated from null mutant
Bcbot4 Δ
.

subSection.paragraph:
The botcinins and botrylactones, compounds 2–6 and those described in this article 21–23 , are polyketides biosynthesized by sequential assembly of a per-methylated pentaketide (C10) arising from the condensation of an acetate primer unit and four malonate molecules, leading to a botrylactone-like intermediate ( 27 ) yielding botrylactone ( 6 ) or botcinin derivatives 2–5, through “a” route, Fig. 3 , ( Massaroli et al., 2013 ). Preliminary isotopic labelling experiments in which labelled sodium acetates, propionate and S-methylmethionine were fed to
B. cinerea
cultures, clearly demonstrate that botcinin skeleton arise from an acetate-derived polyketide assembled from carbon C-8 to C-1, with its four pendent methyl groups originating from S -adenosylmethylmethionine ( Massaroli et al., 2013 ).

These polyketides require the action of two polyketide synthases (PKS), BcBoa6 and BcBoa9 ( Fig. 3 ). Deletion of either the bcboa6 or bcboa9 gene ( Dalmais et al., 2011 ) showed that they act in concert to synthetize botcinic acid ( 2 ):
Δ bcboa6
and
Δ bcboa9
null mutants did not produce botcinic acid or its derivatives; interestingly
Δ bcboa9
overproduced botrylactone ( 6 ) ( Massaroli et al., 2013 ; Porquier et al., 2019 ; Dalmais et al., 2011 ).

Further isotopic labelling experiments showed that BcBoa6 mediates the formation of the pentaketide core, common to both botcinins and botrylactones, whereas BcBoa9 is responsible for the 7- O -acyltetraketide side chain of botcinic acid and its derivatives 2–4 ( Massaroli et al., 2013 ; Dalmais et al., 2011 ). These results enabled us to propose the biosynthetic route showed in Fig. 3 , where the acetate starter unit in botcinins is lost through a retro-Claisen type C–C bond cleavage of the botrylactone-like precursor 26 . The starter unit remaining attached at position C-3 of the botcinin molecule. Therefore, the 3- O -acetyl group in botcinins (4, 5 ) and 3-acetylbotcinic acid ( 29 ) is derived from the starter unit of the botrylactone precursors 26 and 27 ( Fig. 3 ) ( Massaroli et al., 2013 ; Porquier et al., 2019 ).

Interestingly, the isolation of compound 24 was relevant insofar as a study of its potential biosynthesis showed that it was apparently biosynthesized from the initial per-methylated pentaketide core, obtained by condensation of four malonate molecules and one acetate unit, without losing the starting acetate unit. Botcinin K has to be synthetized from pentaketide (C10) which, after methylation by S-adenosyl methyl methionine and adequate functionalization and cyclization, give the pyrane intermediate 26 ( Fig. 3 ). This key intermediate is apparently hydroxylated at C-5 giving intermediate 28 , pathway “b”, and, after esterifications at C-5 and C-7, directly yields the botcinin K ( 24 ), where the acetate starter unit now appearing at carbon C-8, carbons C-9 and C-10.

Lastly, the 1 H NMR signals of compound 25 resembled those of cinbotolide ( 7 ) ( Botubol et al., 2014 ). However, the molecular formula for this compound was established as C 12 H 18 O 5 [M-H 2 O] + by HRMS indicating that 25 is a tetraketide, with four methyl groups and two degrees of unsaturation, instead of a pentaketide. This was consistent with the 13 C NMR and HSQC data. The 13 C NMR revealed the presence of four methyl, five methine groups and three quaternary carbons, one corresponding to a carbonyl group at δ 176.5 ppm attributed to a γ- lactone, and two bore an oxygen function, one of which corresponds to a hemiketalic carbon at δ 106.0 ppm. The 1 H NMR spectrum contained four, three-proton signals, two singlets (δ 1.35 (H-10) and 1.42 (H-12)) and two doublets (δ 1.23 ( J = 7.1 Hz, H-9) and 1.34 ( J = 7.2 Hz), H-11). There were three signals (doublets) in the 1 H NMR that were assigned to protons geminal to hydroxyl groups at δ 4.09 (d, J = 4.1 Hz), 4.25 (d, J = 7.0 Hz) and 3.9 (d, J = 5.9 Hz). Based on the HMBC correlations observed, the signals were attributed to protons H-3, H-5 and H-7, respectively (Table S4). Furthermore, the correlations observed in the HMBC, H-2 with C-1 and C-9; H-3 with the carbonyl C-1, C-4 and C-5; and H-9 with carbons C-1, C-2 and C-3, along with absorption in the IR 1752 cm 1 and the signal at δ 176.5 in the 13 C NMR, were consistent with a γ- lactone. In addition to the correlations of the protons H-10, H-6 and H-7, table S4, which let us to propose the polyketide chain, the correlations between H-5 and C-3, C-4, C-7, C-8 located the hemiketalic closing of the ring B, between C-5 and C-8. Moreover, correlations between H-6 and C-5, C-7, C-11, between H-11 and C-5, C-6, C-7, and H-12 and C-7, C-8 were observed, confirming the structure proposed for compound 25 .

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Conformational disposition and NOE effects observed in compound 25 .

subSection.paragraph: Interestingly, the basic structure of cinbotolide of this compound corresponds with the same basic tetraketide of botcinins, which should be cyclized in different positions. Thus, attack of a hydroxyl group at C-5 to a keto group at C-8 would give ring B, followed by the simultaneous lactonization with the hydroxyl at C-4 to yield 25 . Stereochemistry was then assigned on the basis of the absolute configuration previously assigned to the polyketides of botcinins ( Tani et al., 2005 ) and cinbotolide A ( Botubol et al., 2014 ) and additional nOe experiments.

When H-2 was irradiated, enhancements were observed in the signals corresponding to H-3, H-9 and H-10 and, interestingly, when H-3 was irradiated there were enhancements to the signals corresponding to H-2, H-10 and unexpectedly to H-7, which should have a β disposition. This was confirmed by irradiation of H-7 and then nOe effects were observed at H-3, H-11 and H-12. When H-5 and H-6 were irradiated enhancements of the signals corresponding to H-6 and H-10, and H-5, H-10 and H-11, were observed. The nOe for H-3, H-5, H-6, H-7 were contradictory and surprising and it became necessary to develop a study with molecular models and MM2 calculation of the more stable conformation. So, a plausible explanation of the nOe was obtained whether we consider an interaction of a hydrogen bond between the hydroxyl group at C-3 and the oxygen hemiketalic of the furan cycle. A conformational disposition as displayed in Fig. 4 was adopted for molecule 25 , approaching proton H-3 and H- 7 in the β disposition along with H-11 and H-12. Protons H-5, H-6 and H-10 are situated on the same lateral face making nOe interactions between them possible. Proposed structure 25 was consistent with HSQC, HMBC, COSY and NOE spectra (Table S4). This compound was isolated from
B. cinerea
for the first time and is reported here as a new compound not previously described in the literature and has been named cinbotolide D.

This detailed study of the null mutant
Bcbot4 Δ
has shown that polyketides are overproduced when the biosynthesis of the sesquiterpene botrydial and its derivatives is abolished. The study led us to the isolation and characterization of five undescribed polyketides 21–25 , three derived from botcinic and botcineric acids, botcinins H, I, J ( 21–23 ), one derived from the initial pentaketide, botcinin K ( 24 ), and one cinbotolide derivative, cinbotolide D ( 25 ). The isolation of compound 24 has confirmed the proposed biosynthetic pathway to botcinins and also confirmed the initial synthesis of a pentaketide, by polyketide synthase BcBOA6, that lose the starter acetyl unit to yield botcinic acid and derivatives, ( Fig. 3 ).

The parental strain of
Botrytis cinerea Pers
: Fr. ( Sclerotiniaceae ) used in this work, B05.10, was kindly supplied by P. Tudzinsky ( Quidde et al., 1998 ).

B. cinerea
mutant was cultivated at 23 ◦ C with 24 h daylight. The culture was grown on malt agar medium (MA; 20 g /l. malt extract, 5 g /l yeast extract, 15 g /l Agar), and minimal medium (MMII; 20 g /l glucose, 2 g /l. NaNO 3 , 1 g /l KH 2 PO
4 , 500 mg
/l MgSO 4. 7H 2 O, 500 mg /l KCl, 10 mg /l FeSO 4. 7H 2 O, 15 g /l Agar). The transformation media was a minimal medium supplemented with saccharose (MMV; 20 g /l glucose, 200 g /l saccharose, 2 g /l. NaNO 3 , 1 g /l KH 2 PO
4 , 500 mg
/l MgSO 4. 7H 2 O, 500 mg /l KCl, 10 mg /l FeSO 4. 7H 2 O, 15 g /l Agar). Nourseothricin fungicide (Werner Bioagent, Germany- 70 μg/ml) was used to select
bcbot4 Δ
mutants.

heading.emphasis: 4.3.1. Gene deletion of the cytochrome P450-encoding gene bcbot4

subSection.paragraph:
The
B. cinerea
gene bcbot4 (GenBank: AY277723.2) was deleted by homologous recombination following the methodology already reported for this mutant ( Moraga et al., 2016 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.4. Chemical methods: Analysis of the Bcbot4 Δ metabolite profile

subSection.paragraph: The Bcbot4 null mutant was grown on malt agar medium ( Dalmais et al., 2011 ) at 25 ◦ C to produce mycelium plugs ( 0.8 cm ) that were further used to inoculate the medium for metabolite production. The strain was fermented in solid malt agar medium following the reported protocol ( Moraga et al., 2016 ; Dalmais et al., 2011 ). The solid agar malt medium was extracted with an ultrasonic bath using ethyl acetate (3 × 0.5 vol). The solvent was dried over Na 2 SO 4 and concentrated to dryness.

1 H and 13 C NMR spectra were obtained on Agilent 400 and 500 MHz spectrometers with SiMe 4 as the internal reference at 25 ο C. Mass Spectroscopy (MS) and High Resolution Mass Spectroscopy (HRMS) were performed on a Thermoquest Voyager spectrometer and QTOF mass spectrometer, respectively ( Botubol et al., 2014 ).

4.4.2.1. Botcinin H (21). Colorless oil was isolated as indicated above and its spectroscopic constants were identical to those shown by a compound obtained by hydrolysis of botcinin An under treatment with 30 μl of HCl 12 M, ( Tani et al., 2005 ).

4.4.2.3. Botcinin J (23). Colorless oil. Semi-preparative HPLC: Hex-EtOAc-Me 2 CO 70:20:10; flow 2.5 ml min-1 ; tR = 37.1 min. [ α ]
D
21 -18 (0.01c, CHCl 3 ). IR ν
max (cm -1 )
: 3470, 2940, 1732, 1644, 1220, 1045.
1 H NMR
(500 MHz, CDCl 3 ): δ 0.88 (t, 3H, J = 7.1 Hz, H-10 ′ ), 1.1 (d, 3H, J = 6.3
